title-group.article-title: Is Culture a Problem for Social Psychology?

contrib-group.aff: Department of Psychology, The University of Melbourne.

bio.p: Yoshihisa Kashima's research is concerned with a social psychology of cultural dynamics, namely, the process of cultural formation, maintenance, and transformation by micro-level activities in situ. He has combined cultural comparative, experimental, and formal modelling methods in his research program to examine the dynamics involving culture and self, the formation, maintenance, and transformation of cultural stereotypes, and culture and language use. He has authored or co-authored papers that appeared inPsychological Review, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology,Personality and Social Psychology Review,Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin,Journal of Experimental Social Psychology,Journal of Cross-Cultural PsychologyandAsian Journal of Social Psychologyamong others. He has co-edited books onSocial Psychology and Cultural Context,Self and Identity: Personal, Social, and Symbolic, andStereotype Dynamics. He taught at the University of Queensland and La Trobe University in Australia before he came to the University of Melbourne where he is Professor of Psychology. He holds a Bachelor of Law from Tokyo University, a BA in Psychology from the University of California, Santa Cruz, and a PhD in Psychology from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. He is the current editor ofAsian Journal of Social Psychology.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Culture has been regarded as an anathema to psychology as an empiricist research tradition. Despite the explosive growth of research on culture and psychology over the last decade of the 20thcentury and its importance in Asian social psychology, the ontological and epistemological tension between psychology as a science and psychology as a cultural/historical discipline introduced in the writings of the thinkers of the Enlightenment and counter-Enlightenment still lingers on in the contemporary discourse of psychology. Clifford Geertz once ominously suggested that cultural psychology may have chewed more than it can. In this paper, the interpretive turn in social science as exemplified by writings of Charles Taylor and Paul Ricoeur is reviewed and discussed how it may impinge on the practice of Asian social psychology as an empirical science in methodological, epistemological, and ontological respects. It is argued here that the current practice of Asian social psychology is largely, though not entirely, free of the challenges mounted by these theorists, and that Asian social psychology has an advantage of not encumbered by this traditional tension due to a monist ontology that is prevalent in Asia.
